bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 9, 1923

div1.p: Hansen writes about his work in Colombia. He has seen no yellow fever in Bucaramanga, although the Stegomyia index is high there as well as along the Magdelena River. He discusses other diseases he has encountered there and notes Dunn's work with mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, September 9, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B. Hanson
REPUBLICA DE COLOMBIA
DIRECCION NACIONAL DE HIGIENE
-----
CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
-----
FUNDACION ROCKEFELLER
Junta Internacional de Sanidad
Direccion Categoria “INTERCOM”
----
DR. HENRY HANSON
DIRECTOR
DR. F. A. MILLER
DIRECTOR ASSISTANTE
L. H. DUNN
ENTOMOLOGO E INSPECTOR SUPERVIGILANTE
-----
Bucaramanga,
September 9, 1923.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
At last we are in Bucaramanga after nearly
two months of continuous travel. We would have reached here earlier
had it not been for the fact that I had to wait a week in Barran-
quilla, for my trunks and that when we left Bogata, we went to
Medellin and Ebejico to investigate some cases of illness which
President Nel Opsina thought might be yellow fever. The latter
possibility we soon ruled out by not finding a single breeding
place in either Medellin or Ebejico (of Stegomyia). In addition
the histories which we obtained when we got right down to the
place where the sick were, were not such as to correspond with
yello fever, but more like pernicious malaria of which they
seemed to have some cases in among the “quebradas” which could
not very well be called valleys. It is an extremely rough country
so much so that down in the lower part about Ebejico (which is at
an elevation of about 3600ft) the hills are high and rough and
truly mountainous in character.

The highest point in the range which we crossed in going
from Medellin to Ebejico is a little over 9000ft, and the entire
distance between the two places, of about 25 miles has practically
no stretch of road which can be called level. It is either a con-
tinuous intermittent ascent or descent, and extremely tiring to
both the animals and the riders. In the climb to the first posada
on the return from Ebejico, we had over three hours of continuous
climbing, and then we were not at the top. The climate both at
Medellin and Ebejico was quite ideal, but unfortunately we have
no work at such places so there is no opportunity for us to enjoy
such comforts. The climate in the sections where we will have the
most to do in Colombia is extremely uncomfortable, and one longs
for the comforts of the Peruvian climate.

So far we have been in Bucaramanga six days, and I have not
yet seen a case in which I will accept the diagnosis of yellow
fever. There have been several reported, of which I have seen about
five or six, but none of these have symptoms of genuine yellow
fever. I have seen some cases of relapsing fever, where I have been
able to demonstrate the spirillum in the stained blood smear, but
I am still waiting for a case with the symptomcomplex which I will
admit as yellow fever. There evidently is a great deal of the re-
lapsing fever. Some of the so called cases of yellow fever which I
have seen in the 4th, 5th, 6th, 8th and 11th days have neither shown
the stage of congestion nor the stage of stasis. Neither redness of
the eyes in the early cases nor the yellowness of the convalescent.
Albumen in the urine has been absent, as well as the red and bleed-
Dr. H.R. Carter
2
Sept. 9, 1923.
bleeding gums, nor has there been the characteristic relation
between pulse and temperature, nor the bradycardia of the con-
valescent.

The average Stegomyia (Aedes aegypti) house breeding in-
dex, for the month of August was:
Bucaramanga 10.7%
Giron 3.0%
Rio Negro 2.6%
Florida 1.8%
Piedecuesta 1.0%,

Hence the only place in which the fever could continue propagating
would be here. In the last few days, for the days work the highest
we have found has been 8% one day, the other days it has been 5.6%
and 6%, which is reaching the index of termination of the fever,
especially for a country like this where there undoubtedly are many
immunes in the population.

The charts of cases which Dr. Lopez and Dr. Henao showed me
aat Puerto Berrio and at Medellin of cases of fever which had
occurred in that section, some were quite suggestive of yellow fever
while others were not such as we obtained in the epidemic on the
Pacific Coast.

The Stegomyia index is high at all points along the Magde-
lena River, and inasmuch as this is a campaign for elimination
and the assurance of such a result I think we better attack the
Stegomyia at all the key points on the river, as well as on the
coast. We can do this at a moderately reasonable cost, I think
$12000.00 monthly will do the job. This will mean $6000.00 monthly
for each party concerned, i.e., the Government and the I.H B., be-
sides the overhead which is borne by the I.H.B.

Next week I am sending Dr. Serpa to Cucuta to begin the
complete investigation there, and to start the Stegomyia work, and
to carry it on while the rest of us organize the permanent working
forces here and after that we go down the Magdelena, to the coast.
From there I expect to go to Cucuta by way of Maracaibo, to inspect
and further organize Dr. Serpa's work in case I find it necessary.

It has been very difficult to secure the necessary fish in
this, the Bucaramanga, sector but I am hoping that we shall find it
quite different in the valley of the Magdelena.

There are quite a number of rumors of fever, in different
parts, such as Puerto Santos, Lebrija, etc., which we will look into
on our way back to the Magdelena. I saw some cases of illness in
Puerto Santos on the way here, but they were very clearly malaria,
or possibly both malaria and relapsing fever.

I have seen several cases of what they call espundia here,
which I think are elephantiasis, especially the cases of that kind
which I saw at Ebejico.

Since arriving here Mr. Dunn has been putting in his time
in breeding out the mosquitoes, which the inspectors have brought
in, the main object being to confirm the actual existence of the
Aedes Aegypti, besides collecting and identifying the others. Of
the others we have found, a species of Uraneotanea, Anopheles
Argyritareus, Culex Quinqifasciatus etc.

The waiter in our hotel took sick night before last, and
today while looking for malaria in his blood I found found the
spirilum of relapsing fever. The clinical picture corresponds.
With all good wishes to you and Laura,
